HULLABALOO IS BRILLIANT

TROXELL ELECTED PRESIDENT

VARSITY LOSES TO VIRGINIA

DEFANDORF WINS FOR VARSITY

Seniors' Year Book Is Scholarly, Poetic,
Clever and Entertaining, and the One
Absorbing Thing of Last Week.

Lacrosse Star Chosen to Head Next Year's
Athletic Association—Locker Fee
Resolution Easily Carried.

Track and Field Men Make 45 Points to
the Visitors' 59 Lloyd Stars Captain Wagner Did Not Compete.

Annual St. John's Game a Pitchers' Battle, and Coach Hooper's Youngest
Man Wins A Good Start Made.

"Hullabaloo Fourteen" made his
debut last week and on all sides
was proclaimed -the best yet." Of
course, every member of the Board
and of the senior class; too, would
claim that distinction for his year
book, and such a claim would be
biased. But when the faculty and
other classmen join in the chorus,
the proof is positive. The book was
the one absorbing thing of last
week, and has been thoroughly read
and re-read by nearly all the McCoy Hall people. By them it was
given first rank among the class
volumes of Hopkins history.
In point of cleverness it is perhaps unrivalled. A certain scholarly air pervades the pages, and one
is led to believe that all the quotation dictionaries available have been
ravished for the most suitable poetic
"puffs," "knocks" and parodies to
express Hopkins life and the characteristics of its men.
A large wagon drew up to McCoy Hall on Wednesday morning

Tommy Troxell was elected president of the General Athletic Association at the annual election held
on Wednesday in Hopkins Hall.
The lacrosse star will take up the
reins of office from President Walter Sutton at the end of this academic year.
Interest displayed in the balloting
was keen, and some of the results
were very close. In fact, there was
one tie, which was decided by the
vote of the president.
The resolution providing a raise
of the locker fee from five dollars
to ten dollars, the raise including
towel service and a season ticket to
Hopkins games at Homewood, was
carried overwhelmingly, indicating
the approval of practically the entire
student body. The increased fee,
however, will not become effective
until ratified by the trustees.
Guy Hollyday was made vicepresident by the withdrawal of all
other -candidates for the office.

\ irginia \von the dual track and
field meet on Saturday at Homewood Field, totaling 59 points
against the 'Varsity's 45.
Huntley Lloyd, Freddie Lee and
Huskie Connolly were the Hopkins
stars. Lloyd was the largest point
winner of the games, having won
two firsts and one second. Lee was
first in the mile and second in the
two-mile event. Connolly was first
in the high and second in the broad
jump.
Capt. Harry Wagner of Hopkins
was unable to compete because of a
strained tendon, and Lloyd had to
be put in the too-yard event to take
his place. Lloyd won this event
and also the 220, and was third in
the4'4o.
The coaches were very much
pleased with the showing Hopkins
was able to make and accepted defeat gracefully. There is no question that Virginia has the best track
team in the South, and as such deserved to, win. Post-mortems are

In one of the prettiest pitching
duels ever seen at Homewood, Hopkins won its fourth consecutive
baseball victory over St. John's on
Saturday by the score of 5 to I.
To Defandorf, the freshman
twirler who was called upon at the
eleventh hour after Pieper and Sylvester were laid up by operations
for appendicitis, belongs the credit
for the victory. He was complete
master of the situation at all times,
and worked like a veteran of many
seasons. His control was almost
perfect, and while seven hits were
registered by St. John's none of
them came when they meant runs
until the ninth inning, when Noble
.drove a liner past Webster for a
home run.
The game was sewed up in the
first round. Porter was passed
and stole second. After Webster
fanned, Hicks hit to left and Porter scored. Wilson walked, and the
next man, Lednum, clouted to deep
center for the circuit, bringing the

NEW LOCKER ROOMS TO BE BUILT
Dressing Quarters at Homewood Will
Be Augmented by Extra Building
Under One of the Stands.

A new locker and dressing room
for Hopkins' athletes will be built
this summer under one of the concrete stands at Homewood. The
plans for the building have been
completed, and construction will begin in the near future.
The new quarters will provide
ample space for the accommodation
of the members of all athlet:c teams.
and will, it is hoped, eliminate the
dress:ng-room in the old Country
School gymnasium, which has for
some years been used by the baseball squad. The distance from
Homewood and the inadequate
equipment of this place has been
inconvenient and uncomfortable for
players.
The new rooms will be ready for
use by the national track and field
stars who are to compete in the
Intercollegiates, to be staged at
Homewood during The StarSpangled Banner Centennial next
September. These quarters, with
the present dressing - rooms and
those available in the old Carroll
Mansion and its outbuildings, will
probably provide ample accommodations for the September games.

Society of the Cincinnati.

The Society of the Cincinnati,
one of the most exclusive organizations in the country, which is made
up of citizens of the thirteen original States only, held its triennial
meeting in McCoy Hall on Wednesday and Thursday.
The order was organized by officers of the American and French
armies of the Revolutionary War.
The purpose of the organization is
to "perpetuate the vast event and
the mutual friendships formed under the pressure of common danger
and in many instances cemented by
the blood of the parties."
The executive committee, composed of one member from each of
the thirteen original States, met at
the Belvedere on Tuesday to outline
the program of the convention. The
visiting delegates were received at
McCoy Hall by the members of the
Maryland Cincinnati and were tendered a luncheon at the Johns Hopkins Club. On Wednesday afternoon a business session was held,
and on Thursday the convention adjourned after a short meeting.

Lacrosse League championship indicates that a general iriterest is being
manifested in the Indian game, and
that it will be many, many decades
before it will be abandoned by the
colleges.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 18, 1914.
Long Live Lacrosse.

The. New York Evening Sun said
in a sporting page editorial last
week:
If some quarter century ago the lacrosse moguls had foreseen the result
they would never have changed the
tightly drawn nets in the crosses of
that day for the baggy nets of today.
That chapge has had much to..do with.
the increasing amount of rough play
in the game, and rough play has taken
a hand in ringing the knell of lacrosse
as Canada's national game. As the
hold of lacrosse upon the affections of
the Canadian sporting public has weakened, so has baseball come to create
for itself a larger and a larger place,
until today there is more baseball than
lacrosse played in Canada, and the game
can now be regarded as the Canadian
national. pastime, so far as summer sport
is regarded. With the net lightly drawn,
it took but the slightest touch from an
opposing player's stick to dislodge the
ball., But when the slack net came in,
dislodging the ball from a stick became
a difficult matter, owing to the ball sticking in the crotch of the 'crosse. Players
received some sharp raps. Retaliation
would •follow and then a "free for all
fight." The result has been a decrease
in the game's popularity.

Lacrosse may be losing ground
as the Canadian national game, but
no close observer of college sports
would care to be credited as saying that the game was becoming less
popular in America. As a matter
of fact, lacrosse gives evidence of
becoming a major spring sport in
Eastern institutions. This is proved
by the increased interest shown at
Cornell, Harvard and Lehigh, and
by the fact that recently a twelve
has been organized at Pennsylvania
and recognized by the General Athletic Association.

this season for the Intercollegiate

The M issionary Fund Committee
of the Young Men's Christian Association, which was appointed for
the purpose of raising one hundred
dollars for foreign Young Men's
Christian Association work, has met
with marked success. On Thursday a circular letter was sent to all
the members of the University who
have postoffice boxes. The- letter
explained the demand for funds to
enable general secretaries to answer
the call to foreign fields.
By Friday evening contributions
amounting to $25.15 has been received. Promises of payments to be
made on Monday were received to
the extent of $12 and this amount
'added to the $25 which was given
by a student before the campaign
opened brings the total amount up
to $62.15, leaving $37.85 to be
raised.
The committee differs f r o Ill
others of its kind in that no date
has been set before which the money
must be obtained. The members
have decided to raise $ioo and
"that's all there is to it." Considering the fact that the campaign has
been going only three days and that
there are many students in the University interested in Young M cn's
Christian Association work who
have not yet been approached, the
committee has good cause for optimism. The committee consists of
H. M. Wagner, Hiram W. Woodward and Guy Hollyday (chairman).

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 18, 1914.
TO SURVEY HOMEWOOD
Second-Year Engineering Men to Make
Careful Study of Hills and Dales
of New University Grounds.

Plans have.been completed for
the course in surveying, which will
be given by Dr. Tilden at Homewood immediately following the end
of the examinations.
All second-year "Tech" men who
have not already had considerable
work in the various forms of field
engineering will be required to take
the course. Instruction will be
given in the use and adjustment of
the various instruments, land surveying, topography, curves, leveling, etc. In lact, a complete map
of the Homewood grounds will be
made—each man having a certain
section to plot.
Work will start on. Thursday
afternoon, June 4, and continue
daily thereafter, from eight in the
morning until half-past five in the
afternoon, up to and including July
3. A holiday will be given on Commencement Day, but except for that
the only time• off which the men
will have will be Sundays, as work
will continue all day on Saturdays.
It is thus seen that the course will
be hard work, and it. is quite probable that many of the arts men will
go out to watch their fellow students perspire in the sun as they
run up and down the hills with
level, rod or chain.
Dr. Tilden will have as his assistant J. S. Gorsuch, a graduate
student in civil engineering, who
has had much practical work with
both the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and with the State Roads
Commission.
Among those who expect to take
the course are: Nelson, Barron,
Iddings, Tobias, Wolman, Melamet,
Courtney, Cockey, Wood, Schmidt,
Rutledge, Leitheiser, Webster and
Campbell.
On to Cambridge.

The coaches gave the 'Varsity lacrosse squad a rest during the
greater part of last week, but on
Friday the team started practice in
preparation for . the final game with
Harvard next Saturday at Cambridge.
Hopkins is going to Boston determined to show "fair Harvard'.
howlacrosse is played down ,South.
The game is the second this season betwen these two. rivals, the
'Varsity having bested the Crimson
to 3—in the first setto at
Homewood several weeks ago.
Sixteen men, including Head
'Coach Wolfe and Manager Howell,
will make the trip. The team will
leave Baltimore on Friday and return on Monday.
The 'Varsity expects to win. Although defeated by -Lehigh for the
league championship, it is certain
that, with this single exception, the
team is superior to any collegiate
twelve in the United States.

HULLABALOO IS BRILLIANT
(Continuedfrom page I.)

and Editor Hammond and Business
Manager Getz, with broad smiles of
satisfaction atork well done, stood
by and supervised the unloading of
the books. Immediately distribution
began, and many took an hour off
to glimpse through the pages.
Naturally, the first thing to do was
to look up "my own picture," but
after that the seniors read the books
with difficulty, for there were so
many to crowd about and peer over
their shoulders.
The Hullabaloo is dedicated to Dr.
William H. Welch and an excellent
full-page portrait of the University's executive gives the book a certain style and authority at the outset. President-Elect Goodnow and
honorary president of: the senior
class Kirby Flower Smith have
pages devoted to their portraits.
-The Four Inevitables" — Dean
Griffin, Dr. Ames, Dr. Greene and
Dr. French—are interesting pictures
to keep with the book through life.
There are plenty of drawings.
Although somewhat after t h e
fashion of the rickety old wood cuts
in Caxton's first edition of Chaucer,
they are most entertaining. These
little caricatures are especially appropriate in the class prophecy,
which is given a conspicuous place
in the beginning of the work. The
prophet shows a certain intimacy
with his classmates. He has satirized them with unrestrained boyishness and is rather inclined to believe them a little "devilish," but
nearly all succeed in life—becoming
bishops, rich men, professors,
farmers, et al.
The hazing situation of last November is treated in cartoon and
verse. This is one of the features
of the book. The "Sword of a
Modern Damocles" is another wellwritten poem.
Athletics and the college activities are "covered" well in special departments. Fraternity groups and
rosters are complete.
The business manager, I am sure,
would like us to add that copies
are on sale at the University postoffice.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 18, 1914.

UNIVERSITY NOTES

AT OTHER COLLEGES

Bill Haynes, author, Hopkins
man, actor (having won a name
as a member of the Haresfoot Club
and as Professor Napoleon), former editor of THE NEws-LETTER.
etc., paid several visits to the University (luring the past week to call
upon his friends among the faculty
and students. Bill is in this city for
a while trying to select a positioh
from among three New York and
one Washington offer.

Penn runs a dancing contest
every year for its students.
* * *
Lehigh took Carlisle into its lacrosse camp by the same score that
our team inflicted on the Redskins7 to 2.
* * *
The speeches, rebuttals and bibliographies of the Harvard-Princeton
and the Harvard-Yale 'varsity debates for 1913-1914 are to be published in book form.
* * *
The College Corporation h a s
voted down the proposition to establish a large "commons" at
Brown on account of the expense
that would be involved in such an
undertaking.
* * *
Penn, crippled badly in nearly
every branch of spring sport, has
just lost the services of another of
its sensational mile relay quartet.
Lockwood, next only to Meredith
and Lippincott, has contracted grip
and tonsilitis, and will probably be
out of the Intercollegiates. Shoemaker, stroke on the 'varsity eight,
is thought to have typhoid fever.

1

A party of about a dozen members of Dr. Swartz's Geology I
Class spent Saturday in Yorktown,
Va., inspecting interesting formations there. The men returned to
the city on Sunday night.
THE NEWS - LETTER Board was

the guest of the business department on Tuesday night at a theatre
party to see "The Deep Purple" at
the Auditorium.
The 1914 Hullabaloo will be on
sale at the University postoffice
until after Commencement Week.
Any person not having secured a
copy may purchase one there.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 18, 1914.
Tennis Team Wins and Loses.

W., B. Si A•

420 West Franklin Street

The tennis team traveled to Annapolis twice during the past week.
On Wednesday a match was played
with the crack Navy team, while on
Saturday, St. John's was encountered. Though putting up a game
struggle,the Black and Blue team was
forced to bow to Navy by the score
of four matches to two. Morgan,
as usual, won his match in the
singles, and, with Crawford as his
partner, captured one of the two
doubles matches. Crawford, DuIlray and Hammond lost their
games in the singles, and Hammond
and Corner were defeated in the
remaining doubles contest.
While Hopkins was crushing St.
John's in baseball at Homewood on
Saturday, the tennis team was cleaning up everything in sight on the St.
John's campus in Annapolis. Due
to some misunderstanding, only
three of the Hopkins team—Hammond,Corner and DuBray—took the
trip to the State capital. Though
two of their opponents were sons
of famous Marylanders—Governor
Goldsborough and President Fell of
the University of Maryland — the
Hopkins contingent was merciless,
capturing three singles and the sole
doubles match that was played.
The scores were as follows: DuBray vs. Downs,6-3, 6-8, 6-3; Hammond vs. Goldsborough, 7-5, 4-6,
6-3; Corner vs. Fell, 6-4, 6-3; Hammond and Corner vs. Downs and
Goldsborough, 6-4, 6-4.

"Hullabaloo Fourteen" made his
debut last week and on all sides
was proclaimed -the best yet." Of
course, every member of the Board
and of the senior class; too, would
claim that distinction for his year
book, and such a claim would be
biased. But when the faculty and
other classmen join in the chorus,
the proof is positive. The book was
the one absorbing thing of last
week, and has been thoroughly read
and re-read by nearly all the McCoy Hall people. By them it was
given first rank among the class
volumes of Hopkins history.
In point of cleverness it is perhaps unrivalled. A certain scholarly air pervades the pages, and one
is led to believe that all the quotation dictionaries available have been
ravished for the most suitable poetic
"puffs," "knocks" and parodies to
express Hopkins life and the characteristics of its men.

student body. The increased fee,
however, will not become effective

other -candidates for the office.

NEW LOCKER ROOMS TO BE BUILT
Dressing Quarters at Homewood Will
Be Augmented by Extra Building
Under One of the Stands.

A new locker and dressing room
for Hopkins' athletes will be built
this summer under one of the concrete stands at Homewood. The
plans for the building have been
completed, and construction will begin in the near future.
The new quarters will provide
ample space for the accommodation
of the members of all athlet:c teams.
and will, it is hoped, eliminate the
dress:ng-room in the old Country
School gymnasium, which has for
some years been used by the baseball squad. The distance from
Homewood and the inadequate
equipment of this place has been
inconvenient and uncomfortable for
players.
The new rooms will be ready for
use by the national track and field
stars who are to compete in the
Intercollegiates, to be staged at
Homewood during The StarSpangled Banner Centennial next
September. These quarters, with
the present dressing - rooms and
those available in the old Carroll
Mansion and its outbuildings, will
probably provide ample accommodations for the September games.

Society of the Cincinnati.

The Society of the Cincinnati,
one of the most exclusive organizations in the country, which is made
up of citizens of the thirteen original States only, held its triennial
meeting in McCoy Hall on Wednesday and Thursday.
The order was organized by officers of the American and French
armies of the Revolutionary War.
The purpose of the organization is
to "perpetuate the vast event and
the mutual friendships formed under the pressure of common danger
and in many instances cemented by
the blood of the parties."
The executive committee, composed of one member from each of
the thirteen original States, met at
the Belvedere on Tuesday to outline
the program of the convention. The
visiting delegates were received at
McCoy Hall by the members of the
Maryland Cincinnati and were tendered a luncheon at the Johns Hopkins Club. On Wednesday afternoon a business session was held,
and on Thursday the convention adjourned after a short meeting.

manifested in the Indian game, and
that it will be many, many decades
before it will be abandoned by the
colleges.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 18, 1914.
Long Live Lacrosse.

The. New York Evening Sun said
in a sporting page editorial last
week:
If some quarter century ago the lacrosse moguls had foreseen the result
they would never have changed the
tightly drawn nets in the crosses of
that day for the baggy nets of today.
That chapge has had much to..do with.
the increasing amount of rough play
in the game, and rough play has taken
a hand in ringing the knell of lacrosse
as Canada's national game. As the
hold of lacrosse upon the affections of
the Canadian sporting public has weakened, so has baseball come to create
for itself a larger and a larger place,
until today there is more baseball than
lacrosse played in Canada, and the game
can now be regarded as the Canadian
national. pastime, so far as summer sport
is regarded. With the net lightly drawn,
it took but the slightest touch from an
opposing player's stick to dislodge the
ball., But when the slack net came in,
dislodging the ball from a stick became
a difficult matter, owing to the ball sticking in the crotch of the 'crosse. Players
received some sharp raps. Retaliation
would •follow and then a "free for all
fight." The result has been a decrease
in the game's popularity.

Lacrosse may be losing ground
as the Canadian national game, but
no close observer of college sports
would care to be credited as saying that the game was becoming less
popular in America. As a matter
of fact, lacrosse gives evidence of
becoming a major spring sport in
Eastern institutions. This is proved
by the increased interest shown at
Cornell, Harvard and Lehigh, and
by the fact that recently a twelve
has been organized at Pennsylvania
and recognized by the General Athletic Association.
Such a close race as has been run
this season for the Intercollegiate

of the Young Men's Christian Association, which was appointed for

dollars for foreign Young Men's
Christian Association work, has met
with marked success. On Thursday a circular letter was sent to all

have postoffice boxes. The- letter
explained the demand for funds to
enable general secretaries to answer
the call to foreign fields.
By Friday evening contributions
amounting to $25.15 has been received. Promises of payments to be
made on Monday were received to
the extent of $12 and this amount
'added to the $25 which was given
by a student before the campaign
opened brings the total amount up
to $62.15, leaving $37.85 to be
raised.
The committee differs f r o Ill
others of its kind in that no date
has been set before which the money
must be obtained. The members
have decided to raise $ioo and
"that's all there is to it." Considering the fact that the campaign has
been going only three days and that
there are many students in the University interested in Young M cn's
Christian Association work who
have not yet been approached, the
committee has good cause for optimism. The committee consists of
H. M. Wagner, Hiram W. Woodward and Guy Hollyday (chairman).

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 18, 1914.
TO SURVEY HOMEWOOD
Second-Year Engineering Men to Make
Careful Study of Hills and Dales
of New University Grounds.

Plans have.been completed for
the course in surveying, which will
be given by Dr. Tilden at Homewood immediately following the end
of the examinations.
All second-year "Tech" men who
have not already had considerable
work in the various forms of field
engineering will be required to take
the course. Instruction will be
given in the use and adjustment of
the various instruments, land surveying, topography, curves, leveling, etc. In lact, a complete map
of the Homewood grounds will be
made—each man having a certain
section to plot.
Work will start on. Thursday
afternoon, June 4, and continue
daily thereafter, from eight in the
morning until half-past five in the
afternoon, up to and including July
3. A holiday will be given on Commencement Day, but except for that
the only time• off which the men
will have will be Sundays, as work
will continue all day on Saturdays.
It is thus seen that the course will
be hard work, and it. is quite probable that many of the arts men will
go out to watch their fellow students perspire in the sun as they
run up and down the hills with
level, rod or chain.
Dr. Tilden will have as his assistant J. S. Gorsuch, a graduate
student in civil engineering, who
has had much practical work with
both the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and with the State Roads
Commission.
Among those who expect to take
the course are: Nelson, Barron,
Iddings, Tobias, Wolman, Melamet,
Courtney, Cockey, Wood, Schmidt,
Rutledge, Leitheiser, Webster and
Campbell.
On to Cambridge.

The coaches gave the 'Varsity lacrosse squad a rest during the
greater part of last week, but on
Friday the team started practice in
preparation for . the final game with
Harvard next Saturday at Cambridge.
Hopkins is going to Boston determined to show "fair Harvard'.
howlacrosse is played down ,South.
The game is the second this season betwen these two. rivals, the
'Varsity having bested the Crimson
to 3—in the first setto at
Homewood several weeks ago.
Sixteen men, including Head
'Coach Wolfe and Manager Howell,
will make the trip. The team will
leave Baltimore on Friday and return on Monday.
The 'Varsity expects to win. Although defeated by -Lehigh for the
league championship, it is certain
that, with this single exception, the
team is superior to any collegiate
twelve in the United States.

HULLABALOO IS BRILLIANT
(Continuedfrom page I.)

and Editor Hammond and Business
Manager Getz, with broad smiles of
satisfaction atork well done, stood
by and supervised the unloading of
the books. Immediately distribution
began, and many took an hour off
to glimpse through the pages.
Naturally, the first thing to do was
to look up "my own picture," but
after that the seniors read the books
with difficulty, for there were so
many to crowd about and peer over
their shoulders.
The Hullabaloo is dedicated to Dr.
William H. Welch and an excellent
full-page portrait of the University's executive gives the book a certain style and authority at the outset. President-Elect Goodnow and
honorary president of: the senior
class Kirby Flower Smith have
pages devoted to their portraits.
-The Four Inevitables" — Dean
Griffin, Dr. Ames, Dr. Greene and
Dr. French—are interesting pictures
to keep with the book through life.
There are plenty of drawings.
Although somewhat after t h e
fashion of the rickety old wood cuts
in Caxton's first edition of Chaucer,
they are most entertaining. These
little caricatures are especially appropriate in the class prophecy,
which is given a conspicuous place
in the beginning of the work. The
prophet shows a certain intimacy
with his classmates. He has satirized them with unrestrained boyishness and is rather inclined to believe them a little "devilish," but
nearly all succeed in life—becoming
bishops, rich men, professors,
farmers, et al.
The hazing situation of last November is treated in cartoon and
verse. This is one of the features
of the book. The "Sword of a
Modern Damocles" is another wellwritten poem.
Athletics and the college activities are "covered" well in special departments. Fraternity groups and
rosters are complete.
The business manager, I am sure,
would like us to add that copies
are on sale at the University postoffice.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 18, 1914.

UNIVERSITY NOTES

AT OTHER COLLEGES

Bill Haynes, author, Hopkins
man, actor (having won a name
as a member of the Haresfoot Club
and as Professor Napoleon), former editor of THE NEws-LETTER.
etc., paid several visits to the University (luring the past week to call
upon his friends among the faculty
and students. Bill is in this city for
a while trying to select a positioh
from among three New York and
one Washington offer.

Penn runs a dancing contest
every year for its students.
* * *
Lehigh took Carlisle into its lacrosse camp by the same score that
our team inflicted on the Redskins7 to 2.
* * *
The speeches, rebuttals and bibliographies of the Harvard-Princeton
and the Harvard-Yale 'varsity debates for 1913-1914 are to be published in book form.
* * *
The College Corporation h a s
voted down the proposition to establish a large "commons" at
Brown on account of the expense
that would be involved in such an
undertaking.
* * *
Penn, crippled badly in nearly
every branch of spring sport, has
just lost the services of another of
its sensational mile relay quartet.
Lockwood, next only to Meredith
and Lippincott, has contracted grip
and tonsilitis, and will probably be
out of the Intercollegiates. Shoemaker, stroke on the 'varsity eight,
is thought to have typhoid fever.

1

A party of about a dozen members of Dr. Swartz's Geology I
Class spent Saturday in Yorktown,
Va., inspecting interesting formations there. The men returned to
the city on Sunday night.

the guest of the business department on Tuesday night at a theatre
party to see "The Deep Purple" at
the Auditorium.
The 1914 Hullabaloo will be on
sale at the University postoffice
until after Commencement Week.
Any person not having secured a
copy may purchase one there.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 18, 1914.
Tennis Team Wins and Loses.

W., B. Si A•

420 West Franklin Street

The tennis team traveled to Annapolis twice during the past week.
On Wednesday a match was played
with the crack Navy team, while on
Saturday, St. John's was encountered. Though putting up a game
struggle,the Black and Blue team was
forced to bow to Navy by the score
of four matches to two. Morgan,
as usual, won his match in the
singles, and, with Crawford as his
partner, captured one of the two
doubles matches. Crawford, DuIlray and Hammond lost their
games in the singles, and Hammond
and Corner were defeated in the
remaining doubles contest.
While Hopkins was crushing St.
John's in baseball at Homewood on
Saturday, the tennis team was cleaning up everything in sight on the St.
John's campus in Annapolis. Due
to some misunderstanding, only
three of the Hopkins team—Hammond,Corner and DuBray—took the
trip to the State capital. Though
two of their opponents were sons
of famous Marylanders—Governor
Goldsborough and President Fell of
the University of Maryland — the
Hopkins contingent was merciless,
capturing three singles and the sole
doubles match that was played.
The scores were as follows: DuBray vs. Downs,6-3, 6-8, 6-3; Hammond vs. Goldsborough, 7-5, 4-6,
6-3; Corner vs. Fell, 6-4, 6-3; Hammond and Corner vs. Downs and
Goldsborough, 6-4, 6-4.
